body:
### Feature already in Vim?

No

### Feature description

I would [still](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5604) like to have fuzzy as you type completions in command mode so that one wouldn’t need to resort to plugins like fzf, telescope etc etc.

comment_data.body:
It is possible by plugins.
For example, nvim-cmp or ddc.vim or wilder.

https://github.com/hrsh7th/nvim-cmp/pull/362
https://github.com/Shougo/ddc.vim/issues/32#issuecomment-934195950
If the command line mode supports highlight and virtual text it is useful though.

And if plugin can the current completion mode in the command line, it is better for plugin completion.

`getcmdcompletion()` API?

> [hrsh7th/nvim-cmp#362](https://github.com/hrsh7th/nvim-cmp/pull/362)
> [Shougo/ddc.vim#32 (comment)](https://github.com/Shougo/ddc.vim/issues/32#issuecomment-934195950)

Interesting, thank you!

My personal opinion though is that all completion functionality should be provided by vim/neovim. All the dozens of plugins are just workarounds around the outdated builtin mechanisms.

I’ve tried to add as you type completion to command mode one time by the way. I managed to understand how it works, but It’s almost impossible to change IMHO. The main problem of course is the explicit event loop which makes doing things asynchronously harder which is the reason why command line completions are implemented in a blocking way.

I don't think the feature should be implemented in Vim/neovim.
But for plugins feature should be added like highlight or virtual texts in command line mode.   I think it is neovim's way.

> I’ve tried to add as you type completion to command mode one time by the way. I managed to understand how it works, but It’s almost impossible to change IMHO. The main problem of course is the explicit event loop which makes doing things asynchronously harder which is the reason why command line completions are implemented in a blocking way.

Of course, I have tried it in some years ago and I have failed it.
Please read this.

https://github.com/Shougo/deoplete.nvim/issues/951

But it is already succeeded.  The plugins does not use Vim/neovim native popup menu feature.

> I don't think the feature should be implemented in Vim/neovim. But for plugins feature should be added like highlight or virtual texts in command line mode. I think it is neovim's way.
> 
> > I’ve tried to add as you type completion to command mode one time by the way. I managed to understand how it works, but It’s almost impossible to change IMHO. The main problem of course is the explicit event loop which makes doing things asynchronously harder which is the reason why command line completions are implemented in a blocking way.
> 
> Of course, I have tried it in some years ago and I have failed it. Please read this.
> 
> [Shougo/deoplete.nvim#951](https://github.com/Shougo/deoplete.nvim/issues/951)
> 
> But it is already succeeded. The plugins does not use Vim/neovim native popup menu feature.

My argument on whether this should be builtin feature or not is simple. If it shouldn’t then neither should be original vim  completion functionality. Which is maybe fine, but no one seems to mention that. What’s your opinion on that?

By that argument, either ALL THE THINGS have to be built in, or none. Such reductionist arguments are not constructive. Rather, for every feature there is a variety of aspects that have to be weighted: how simple is it to implement; what are the _technical_ advantages for being in core (having functionality in optional plugins is a _feature_ of *vim!); how much maintenance burden does it add etc.

The net result for completion was positive (especially since Vim already did the work); the case for _fuzzy_ completion is much weaker.

I think command line completion popup menu can be built-in.
But auto completion feature should not.

> I think command line completion popup menu can be built-in.

And it already is, no? `:set wildoptions=pum`
`set wildoptions=pum` cannot be used from plugins unfortunately.

Related issue:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12620

I think Vim/neovim core should provide features to create plugins easily like popup menu, timer, highlight, virtual text etc.
Current Vim/neovim implementation is very complex.  Have you read the code?
I don't think every features should be built-in.

> Related issue: #12620
> 
> I think Vim/neovim core should provide features to create plugins easily like popup menu, timer, highlight, virtual text etc. Current Vim/neovim implementation is very complex. Have you read the code? I don't think every features should be built-in.

It is complex, but I would say unnecessarily so. IMHO this should be solved by refactoring not by offloading more and more responsibilities to plugins. Whether such refactoring is actually feasible is a different question. But if it isn’t (as the case with any refactoring) it means that the codebase is doomed.

> It is complex, but I would say unnecessarily so. IMHO this should be solved by refactoring not by offloading more and more responsibilities to plugins. Whether such refactoring is actually feasible is a different question. But if it isn’t (as the case with any refactoring) it means that the codebase is doomed.

You can refactor it.  It is open source.

And if the feature is really needed, why don't you send the PR?
neovim already has many issues and feature requests and the developers are already have been busy.  I think other feature is high priority.  But you can do it instead of other developers.

For example, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/4382 is important for me than the feature.

@purpleP Let me be very clear here: there are currently _zero_ plans for having builtin autocompletion, and even less so for the commandline. Furthermore, "offloading more and more responsibilities to plugins" is very much by design and has served us well so far. If you are not happy with the fundamental goals of this project, you are welcome to look at other editors; maybe https://github.com/helix-editor/helix suits you better.

> set wildoptions=pum cannot be used from plugins unfortunately.

you mean `complete()` and related functions in cmdline mode? That would be a useful _core_ addition (mechanism, not policy).
Yes.

> @purpleP Let me be very clear here: there are currently _zero_ plans for having builtin autocompletion, and even less so for the commandline. Furthermore, "offloading more and more responsibilities to plugins" is very much by design and has served us well so far. If you are not happy with the fundamental goals of this project, you are welcome to look at other editors; maybe https://github.com/helix-editor/helix suits you better.

Oh, you do whatever you like. I’m just expressing my opinion and asking what are you guys thinking. It’s not about complaining.

I’ve seen kakoune and helix and disagree with the core design. I like how vim language more as it is explicit. I was excited about xi, but it didn’t work out.

I guess one day I would just have to copy ropes implementation from xi and build my own vi clone around it.
_(Updated comment here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16142#issuecomment-1134591004)_

@justinmk In the days before language servers I remember that some plugins just remapped certain characters such as dot to trigger completion.

I would guess that deciding when to show a completion is the only thing missing in the core to make it into “as you type”. If so now that you’ve integrated tree-sitter maybe it just comes down to making a list of predicates over `TSNode` that would tell when to trigger completion? Does tree-sitter support that?

> @purpleP Let me be very clear here: there are currently _zero_ plans for having builtin autocompletion, and even less so for the commandline. Furthermore, "offloading more and more responsibilities to plugins" is very much by design and has served us well so far. If you are not happy with the fundamental goals of this project, you are welcome to look at other editors; maybe https://github.com/helix-editor/helix suits you better.

You see I’m not developing neovim so I’m not trying to influence your decisions or something. What I would like is a clear understanding of whether such and such feature would be implemented or not and why.

For example If you decided to offload more and more functionality to plugins - have you decided to offload completion or not?

If not, then why not make it better out of the box to match other editors?

If yes, then why don’t make plans to remove it altogether and mark code as deprecated so that no one would work on that.

It might be a lot of questions and you can just answer that you don’t have time for that. That’s okay 👌.
I already addressed this in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16142#issuecomment-951938030

> I already addressed this in [#16142 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16142#issuecomment-951938030)

Oh, sorry haven’t seen it.

So you’re saying you had a discussion about it and decided what exactly? Can I see this discussion somewhere?

The other thing is that I don’t see this as “reductionist” or whatever. I don’t see anything wrong with clearly defining what should be in the core and what should be implemented in plugins. For example core can only have editing operations, window management, vim bindings and language, vimscript. Something like that.

This is getting off-topic for a Github issue, which should be focused on a specific feature.

But this is discussed for each feature suggestion separately: what are the advantages of having it in core? do they outweigh the disadvantages (added documentation surface and maintenance burden; being tied to Nvim's release cycle for updates)? It doesn't make sense to draw hard lines _now_, as that will leave you unable to react to future developments (case in point: LSP).

Now, original vim has support of fuzzy completion on cmdline. It will resolve this issue.

ref: https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/38b85cb4d7216705058708bacbc25ab90cd61595
That one is still manual completion, not autocompletion.

> I would guess that deciding when to show a completion is the only thing missing in the core to make it into “as you type”.

@purpleP this is a good callout. Seems very useful to have in core.

# Status

Topics covered in this issue:

1. As-you-type is _autocompletion_ (as opposed to mere "completion"). We want to have strong primitives for building autocomplete solutions:
    - Function that decides _when to trigger autocomplete_ (based on buffer text + cursor position)
    - Anything else...?
2. "fuzzy" matching / completion:
    - https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13854
    - https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/12995
3. cmdline (command line) mode
    - CursorMovedC was added in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29436

> @purpleP Let me be very clear here: there are currently zero plans for having builtin autocompletion, and even less so for the commandline. Furthermore, "offloading more and more responsibilities to plugins" is very much by design and has served us well so far. If you are not happy with the fundamental goals of this project, you are welcome to look at other editors; maybe https://github.com/helix-editor/helix suits you better.

@clason 

Priorities do get revisited, though, as the world around us changes.

And for many other ecosystems I've seen, if there is a plugin system and there are many plugins doing the same thing, some of the functionality in those most popular plugins does get dragged into the core system.

Fuzzy file search, at least, for the existing vim-derived command line primitives would make neovim a lot more usable out of the box.

> Priorities do get revisited, though, as the world around us changes.

And yet these priorities haven't changed in the meantime.

> I would guess that deciding when to show a completion is the only thing missing in the core to make it into “as you type”.

@purpleP this is a good callout. Seems very useful to have in core.

# Status

`:help fuzzy-matching` is part of core now. Remaining work is tracked here:

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12428
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16488
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25670
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12620

Topics covered in this issue:

1. As-you-type is _autocompletion_ (as opposed to mere "completion"). We want to have strong primitives for building autocomplete solutions:
    - Function that decides _when to trigger autocomplete_ (based on buffer text + cursor position)
    - Anything else...?
2. "fuzzy" matching / completion:
    - https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13854
    - https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/12995
3. cmdline (command line) mode
    - CursorMovedC was added in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29436

---
_Locked to keep the summary visible. You can always [chat](https://neovim.io/#chat) or open an issue if you have new information/topics to discuss._

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: autocomplete: fuzzy match, trigger (also in cmdline)
